docs.abstract: The maverick artist, the subject of two exhibitions, is known for his grueling street performances, but his real enchantment lies in something weirder.
docs.snippet: The maverick artist, the subject of two exhibitions, is known for his grueling street performances, but his real enchantment lies in something weirder.
docs.lead_paragraph: Artists often adopt personas in their work — master painter, trickster, savant — and you can see this in the 13 performances of the maverick artist William Pope.L at the Museum of Modern Art. And he uses the characters in his show, “member: Pope.L, 1978-2001,” to critique race and class in the United States.

headline.main: What Makes Pope.L’s Art Endure? (It’s Not the Famous Crawls)
headline.print_headline: Not Just Crawling Across the Art World

docs.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
docs.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
docs.lead_paragraph: How should one live? It’s a brief, potent and timeless question, explored in a few of this week’s recommended books. In her debut memoir, “Uncanny Valley,” Anna Wiener recounts leaving her low-paying publishing job for Silicon Valley, and the ensuing optimism and disenchantment she experienced. In the darkly comic novel “The Heap,” Sean Adams explores what happens to survivors after a skyscraping utopia collapses. Another collapse — this time of a steeple — occurs in Sylvia Townsend Warner’s “The Corner That Held Them,” a novel that immerses readers in the daily life of a 14th-century English convent.

headline.main: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
headline.print_headline: Staff Picks From the Book Review

docs.abstract: The queen had yet to give her approval to their idea of becoming part-time royals, but word of the plan was about to leak.
docs.snippet: The queen had yet to give her approval to their idea of becoming part-time royals, but word of the plan was about to leak.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, failed to get clearance from Queen Elizabeth II before announcing their unorthodox plan to become part-time, financially independent royals and divide their time between Britain and North America.

headline.main: Going Rogue: Prince Harry and Meghan Caught the Palace Off Guard
headline.print_headline: Going Rogue: Prince Harry and Meghan Surprised the Palace

docs.abstract: Some scientists hope genomic technologies will lead to improved antivenom.
docs.snippet: Some scientists hope genomic technologies will lead to improved antivenom.
docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have sequenced the genome of one of the deadliest snakes in the world, the Indian cobra, and have taken a big step toward developing new and better treatments for their bites.

headline.main: When the Cobra Bites, You’ll Be Glad Someone Sequenced Its Genome
headline.print_headline: Venomous Research: Fighting Cobra Bites By Getting a Grip On Its Genome

docs.abstract: Lessons in the art of listening, from a C.I.A. agent, a focus group moderator and more.
docs.snippet: Lessons in the art of listening, from a C.I.A. agent, a focus group moderator and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: When was the last time you listened to someone? Really listened, without thinking about what you wanted to say next, glancing down at your phone or jumping in to offer your opinion? And when was the last time someone really listened to you? Was so attentive to what you were saying and whose response was so spot on that you felt truly understood?

headline.main: Talk Less. Listen More. Here’s How.
headline.print_headline: Lessons in the Lost Art of Listening

docs.abstract: Across America, working-class people — including many of our friends — are dying of despair. And we’re still blaming the wrong people.
docs.snippet: Across America, working-class people — including many of our friends — are dying of despair. And we’re still blaming the wrong people.
docs.lead_paragraph: YAMHILL, Ore. — Chaos reigned daily on the No. 6 school bus, with working-class boys and girls flirting and gossiping and dreaming, brimming with mischief, bravado and optimism. Nick rode it every day in the 1970s with neighbors here in rural Oregon, neighbors like Farlan, Zealan, Rogena, Nathan and Keylan Knapp.

byline.original: By Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn
